formats.name: haiku_reaction
formats.instruction: Summarize your reaction to a topic or event in a traditional haiku: three lines (5-7-5 syllables). Use vivid imagery.

formats.name: imaginary_interview
formats.instruction: Conduct a mock interview with a famous person (real or fictional), asking and answering 2-3 intriguing questions as both interviewer and interviewee.

formats.name: reverse_advice
formats.instruction: Describe something you did wrong, then tell readers what NOT to do. Frame your post as anti-advice — highlight pitfalls, mistakes, and what you learned.

formats.name: hyper_short_manifesto
formats.instruction: Write a bold manifesto statement for or against something in just TWO sentences. Make it punchy and memorable.

formats.name: parallel_worlds
formats.instruction: Describe how something would unfold in an alternate timeline. Compare real events with your imagined version in two distinct paragraphs.

formats.name: pocket_lecture
formats.instruction: Write a condensed lecture on a niche topic, including a thesis, supporting facts, and a provocative closing question. Aim to inform and spark thought.

formats.name: emoji_sequence_story
formats.instruction: Tell a story using a sequence of 10-15 emojis, then give a 2-3 sentence explanation of the plot.

formats.name: overheard_conversation
formats.instruction: Write a transcript of a short, overheard conversation (real or imagined) relevant to the topic. Include speaker labels and at least three lines of dialogue.

formats.name: time_capsule_reflection
formats.instruction: Compose a message addressed to your future self (5-10 years from now), reflecting on today’s topic and speculating how it might change.

title_styles: Write a playful or mischievous title. Examples: 'Why my socks rebelled this morning', 'In defense of the midnight pickle snack', 'How not to launch your hot air balloon'
Write a warning or cautionary title. Examples: 'Do NOT try this at home', 'Don't believe everything you hear about X', 'The mistake everyone makes with Y'
Write an ironic or tongue-in-cheek title. Examples: 'The flawless guide to failing spectacularly', 'How to lose friends and mislabel plants', 'You definitely don't need this tip'
Write a speculative title about alternate outcomes. Examples: 'If history had gone left instead of right', 'What if our coffee was blue?', 'The day gravity reversed'
Write a title using only questions. Examples: 'What happens if you never delete your emails?', 'Is it possible to eat soup with a fork?', 'Who decides what is normal?'
structure_variants: Alternately switch between present and past tense in each paragraph.
Write as a mini-script, indicating scene changes, dialogue, and stage directions.
Use bullet points ONLY, no sentences — each bullet must convey a distinct idea or scene.
Include a surprising twist halfway through, marked by a one-sentence reveal.
Write as an open letter, addressing someone or something directly throughout.
topic_angles: Everyday rituals that secretly shape our routines
The invisible economics of sharing snacks
The impact of imaginary friends on adult creativity
Small miscommunications that led to big changes
